title: Java Mathexp()Method

metadata.description: Learn about Java Mathexp()Method with clear explanations and practical examples.

content_sections.title: Details
content_sections.content:
Example
Return
e
raised to the power of different numbers:
System.out.println(Math.exp(0));
System.out.println(Math.exp(1));
System.out.println(Math.exp(10));
System.out.println(Math.exp(4.8));
System.out.println(Math.exp(Math.E));

Definition and Usage
The
exp()
method returns
e
raised to the power of a number (
e
x
).
e
is the base of the natural system of logarithms (approximately 2.718282). In Java, the value of
e
is available as the constant
Math.E
.
Syntax
public static double exp(double
number
)
Parameter Values
Parameter
Description
number
Required. The power to which
e
is raised.
Technical Details
Returns:
A
double
value representing the result of
e
to the power of a number.
Java version:
Any

★
+1

quiz.question: What is e?
options: the base of the natural system of logarithms (approximately 2
quiz.explanation: The correct definition of e is 'the base of the natural system of logarithms (approximately 2'.

quiz.question:
What is the value of
e?
options: the base of the natural system of logarithms (approximately 2
quiz.explanation:
The correct definition of the value of
e is 'available as the constant
Math'.

summary: This tutorial covers Java Mathexp()Method concepts and techniques. You'll learn how to use Java Mathexp()Method effectively, including key principles, common patterns, and practical examples. By the end of this tutorial, you'll have a solid understanding of Java Mathexp()Method and how to apply it in your projects.
